posts.name: Joseph Gonzalo Amador
posts.cooked: My team is attempting to correct the robot’s pose by using the addVisionMeasurement function built into CTRE ’s swerve code. However, no matter how much I change the standard deviations the vision measurement does not affect the pose I get from getState().pose. I was wondering if any other teams were running into this same issue and if there’s a solution.

link_counts.title: Photonvision returning the same exact pose every time
New Swerve Phoenix API not behaving correctly

posts.name: Wilson
posts.cooked:
I had the exact same issue. Was considering opening an issue in GitHub.

In the meantime I just made a second pose estimator object in the drivetrain subsystem.

posts.name: Joseph Gonzalo Amador
posts.cooked: I tried doing it manually using the SwerveDrivePoseEstimator but there were a lot of weird issues. Could you share how you implemented yours?

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: As is mentioned in our API documentation and demonstrated in our SwerveWithPathPlanner and SwerveWithChoreo examples, you must make sure the timestamp is in the correct timebase. In this case, Limelight reports an FPGA timestamp, so you must convert it to the correct timebase using Utils.fpgaToCurrentTime(LLposeEstimate.timestampSeconds) .

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Joseph Gonzalo Amador
posts.cooked: The code I shared doesn’t have that but I have tried that and it didn’t seem to change anything.

posts.name: Joseph Gonzalo Amador
posts.cooked: One thing I noticed while poking around in the CTRE SwerveDrivetrain class is that in the Function comment for addVisionMeaurement says “This method can be called as infrequently as you want, as long as you are * calling { @link SwerveDrivePoseEstimator#update} every loop.” Maybe the update function isn’t being called?

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
Joseph_Amador:

Maybe the update function isn’t being called?

The update function is called internally by our odometry thread, by default at 100 Hz on CAN 2.0 and 250 Hz on CAN FD.

Joseph_Amador:

The code I shared doesn’t have that but I have tried that and it didn’t seem to change anything.

Can you look at the output of Utils.fpgaToCurrentTime(LLposeEstimate.timestampSeconds) compared to Utils.getCurrentTimeSeconds() ? They should be fairly close (within 0.050 seconds), given that all the function does is take the difference between our clock and the FPGA clock and add it to the FPGA timestamp.

posts.name: Joseph Gonzalo Amador
posts.cooked:
I can check that tomorrow.

In the meantime, I captured this log file from earlier today. The Manual pose is my limelight’s pose estimate and Fused PoseDBL is the pose I got from getstate().pose. FRC_20250115_170742.zip (3.1 MB)

Running this code: https://github.com/TheMathWiz56/2848_Reefscape/tree/31d81315a0be0cd36f0ce6c3a5760071783bc21e

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
In that code base, I see a commit where you called addVisionMeasurement without using Utils.fpgaToCurrentTime , and then a commit using a local pose estimator with Utils.fpgaToCurrentTime . However, those would be backwards; our addVisionMeasurement requires Utils.fpgaToCurrentTime , while your local one (which is WPILib’s) requires that you do NOT use Utils.fpgaToCurrentTime .

The log also looks like it was without any usage of Utils.fpgaToCurrentTime , although it’s hard to tell because timestamps aren’t logged.

Based on that, it’s not clear to me if you’ve tried using our addVisionMeasurement with the Utils.fpgaToCurrentTime change. If you haven’t, then I would revert the switch to a local pose estimator, add the call to Utils.fpgaToCurrentTime , and check the results.

posts.name: Joseph Gonzalo Amador
posts.cooked: Gotchya, tomorrow I will switch back to CTRE ’s poseEstimator and try changing FPGA to current time.

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
It looks like you’re getting the pose estimate from the get_manual_LL_Estimate() method, which does not read a timestamp. I would recommend using the getBotPoseEstimate() method from LimelightHelpers as a starting point, which reads the timestamp from NetworkTables with appropriate latency adjustments.

Of course, you also need to properly convert to CTRE ’s non-FPGA time base as explained previously.

posts.name: Joseph Gonzalo Amador
posts.cooked: Will do. I switched to the manual LL estimate since the wpibotpose_orb_wpiblue isn’t working properly with the new field size.

posts.name: Joseph Gonzalo Amador
posts.cooked: Converting the timestamp worked, thanks for the help.
